newsitem.title: USA: House Democrat hits administration Hispanic hiring.
newsitem.headline: House Democrat hits administration Hispanic hiring.

text.p: Senior Hispanic House Democrats Thursday criticised the Clinton administration for what they said was an unacceptably low level of Hispanics among federal employees.

"The Clinton administration, in its second term, has dropped to a new low in Latino representation among federal employees," Representative Esteban Torres of California said at a news conference with some of the other 19 members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus.
Torres said Hispanics now made up less than five percent of the federal workforce compared to a high of almost eight percent during Clinton's first term.
"Talented Latino men and women continue to knock at the door of the administration for an opportunity to serve their nation," Torres said.
Clinton's 20-member cabinet has two Hispanics, the same number as in his first term: Energy Secretary Federico Pena and U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Bill Richardson.
Pena was transportation secretary in Clinton's first term. Housing Secretary Henry Cisneros, the other Hispanic cabinet member, resigned in January.
